myq.eli5: MyQ is like a remote control for your garage door you can use from anywhere.
myq.boss: MyQ is a smart garage door opener platform from Chamberlain that enables remote monitoring and control via mobile app or integrations.
myq.sysadmin: MyQ devices communicate over Wi-Fi and use proprietary cloud APIs. While closed-source, some integrations exist via HomeBridge and MQTT workarounds.
myq.use_case: Used to open or close a garage door from your phone while away from home.

augustsmartlock.eli5: August is like a magic lock you can open with your phone instead of a key.
augustsmartlock.boss: August Smart Locks retrofit your existing deadbolt, enabling keyless entry and app control with integration into smart home ecosystems.
augustsmartlock.sysadmin: August locks use Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and Z-Wave (Pro models), supporting HomeKit, Alexa, Google, and automations with optional bridge.
augustsmartlock.use_case: Used to unlock your door remotely for a visitor while you're at work.

yaleassurelock.eli5: Yale Assure is a lock that doesn’t need a key—it uses a keypad or your phone.
yaleassurelock.boss: Yale Assure Lock is a smart deadbolt with keyless entry, offering support for major smart home platforms.
yaleassurelock.sysadmin: Yale Assure Lock supports Z-Wave, Zigbee, and Wi-Fi modules for integration with systems like SmartThings, HomeKit, and Alexa.
yaleassurelock.use_case: Used to allow keypad-based or app-based entry into your home without a physical key.

levellock.eli5: Level Lock hides all the smart stuff inside the door so it looks like a regular lock.
levellock.boss: Level Lock is a discreet smart lock designed to fit inside traditional hardware while supporting modern features and automation.
levellock.sysadmin: Level Lock works via Bluetooth and HomeKit (or Matter), with some models using Thread for low-energy smart home integration.
levellock.use_case: Used to make a front door smart without changing the appearance of the existing lock.

schlageencode.eli5: Schlage Encode is a smart lock that talks to your Wi-Fi so you can control it anywhere.
schlageencode.boss: Schlage Encode is a smart lock series with built-in Wi-Fi for keyless entry, remote access, and voice assistant integration.
schlageencode.sysadmin: Schlage Encode operates over Wi-Fi and supports Alexa and Google Assistant, with app control and encryption for remote locking.
schlageencode.use_case: Used to create temporary codes for guests and lock/unlock via app remotely.

nuki.eli5: Nuki is a smart key turner that lets your phone lock or unlock the door.
nuki.boss: Nuki is a smart lock system popular in Europe that attaches to existing locks for app and remote control.
nuki.sysadmin: Nuki Smart Locks support Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional bridge integrations for Apple HomeKit, Alexa, Google, and web APIs.
nuki.use_case: Used to auto-unlock the door as you arrive home using Bluetooth proximity.

smartlock.eli5: A smart lock is like a regular lock, but you can unlock it with your phone or a code.
smartlock.boss: Smart locks replace or augment traditional door locks, enabling keyless entry and remote control via apps or automation.
smartlock.sysadmin: Smart locks use Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, Z-Wave, Zigbee, or Thread to communicate with hubs, assistants, or mobile apps for access control.
smartlock.use_case: Used to lock your door automatically when you leave the house using geofencing.

smartthermostat.eli5: It’s a smart temperature knob that knows when to turn the heat or AC up or down.
smartthermostat.boss: Smart thermostats automate home heating and cooling based on schedules, presence, and voice or app control.
smartthermostat.sysadmin: Smart thermostats connect over Wi-Fi, supporting platforms like Alexa, Google, HomeKit, and can integrate with sensors and IFTTT.
smartthermostat.use_case: Used to automatically reduce heating when nobody is home, saving energy.

smartplug.eli5: A smart plug is like a remote switch you can control with your phone.
smartplug.boss: Smart plugs allow you to remotely control and automate power to devices using an app or voice assistant.
smartplug.sysadmin: Smart plugs communicate over Wi-Fi, Zigbee, or Z-Wave and support schedules, energy monitoring, and automation triggers.
smartplug.use_case: Used to automate lamps or coffee makers based on time or scenes.

smartswitch.eli5: A smart switch is a light switch you can tap in real life or on your phone.
smartswitch.boss: Smart switches replace traditional wall switches to allow for remote, voice, and automated control of lights or fans.
smartswitch.sysadmin: Smart switches use Wi-Fi, Zigbee, or Z-Wave and integrate with platforms like Home Assistant, Alexa, and Google Home.
smartswitch.use_case: Used to control lights via app, voice, or motion sensor triggers.

smartbulb.eli5: A smart bulb is a light that can change colors or turn on/off using your phone or voice.
smartbulb.boss: Smart bulbs are Wi-Fi or Zigbee-enabled lights that support remote control, dimming, color changes, and automation.
smartbulb.sysadmin: Smart bulbs use protocols like Zigbee, Z-Wave, Bluetooth, or Wi-Fi, and can integrate with platforms like Alexa, Google, and Home Assistant.
smartbulb.use_case: Used to schedule lights to turn on at sunset or respond to voice commands.

smartoutlet.eli5: A smart outlet is like a power socket you can turn on and off with your phone.
smartoutlet.boss: Smart outlets let you control plugged-in devices remotely and can track energy usage.
smartoutlet.sysadmin: Smart outlets are typically Wi-Fi, Zigbee, or Z-Wave controlled devices that support toggling power, automation, and reporting via API or app.
smartoutlet.use_case: Used to cut power to a space heater remotely for safety.

smartdimmer.eli5: A smart dimmer is a light switch that lets you adjust brightness from your phone.
smartdimmer.boss: Smart dimmers allow remote or automated control of lighting levels via apps, voice assistants, or schedules.
smartdimmer.sysadmin: Smart dimmers use Zigbee, Z-Wave, or Wi-Fi, and typically require a neutral wire; some offer scene control and multi-tap triggers.
smartdimmer.use_case: Used to gradually dim bedroom lights at night for better sleep.

smartfancontroller.eli5: It’s like a smart light switch, but for your ceiling fan speed.
smartfancontroller.boss: Smart fan controllers automate and remotely control ceiling fan speed using voice or app interfaces.
smartfancontroller.sysadmin: Smart fan controllers use Wi-Fi, Z-Wave, or Zigbee and support multiple speed settings, often integrated into wall switches.
smartfancontroller.use_case: Used to automatically set fan speed based on room temperature or schedule.

ceilingfanmodule.eli5: This hides in your fan and makes it smart—without changing your switch.
ceilingfanmodule.boss: Ceiling fan modules convert standard fans into smart devices controlled via apps or voice assistants.
ceilingfanmodule.sysadmin: Modules install inside the fan housing and use protocols like RF, Zigbee, or Wi-Fi, often paired with hubs like Bond or BroadLink.
ceilingfanmodule.use_case: Used to upgrade a ceiling fan to work with Alexa and schedules without replacing the wall switch.

garagedooropener.eli5: A garage door opener lets you open the big car door with a button—or your phone if it’s smart.
garagedooropener.boss: Smart garage door openers allow remote control, alerts, and automation for your garage from anywhere.
garagedooropener.sysadmin: Smart openers use Wi-Fi or integrate with hubs to control relays and sensors, often via apps, Alexa, Google, or MyQ systems.
garagedooropener.use_case: Used to auto-close the garage if left open after 10 PM.

smartsensor.eli5: Smart sensors notice things—like motion or water—and tell your smart home about it.
smartsensor.boss: Smart sensors detect conditions like motion, temperature, or water and trigger automation actions or alerts.
smartsensor.sysadmin: Smart sensors use Zigbee, Z-Wave, Wi-Fi, or BLE to transmit event data and often support battery monitoring and tamper alerts.
smartsensor.use_case: Used to turn on hallway lights when motion is detected at night.

contactsensor.eli5: A contact sensor tells you if a door or window is open or closed.
contactsensor.boss: Contact sensors detect the open or closed state of doors, windows, or drawers and trigger automations or alerts.
contactsensor.sysadmin: Typically Zigbee or Z-Wave based, contact sensors use magnetic fields to detect state changes and send events to hubs or assistants.
contactsensor.use_case: Used to send a phone alert if a door is opened while the system is armed.

motionsensor.eli5: Motion sensors are like smart eyes that know when something moves.
motionsensor.boss: Motion sensors detect movement and trigger smart home events like lighting or alerts.
motionsensor.sysadmin: These sensors use PIR (passive infrared), microwave, or mmWave tech and report activity via Zigbee, Z-Wave, or Wi-Fi.
motionsensor.use_case: Used to turn on lights in a hallway when someone walks by.

vibrationsensor.eli5: It feels when something shakes or moves—like if someone knocks or tampers.
vibrationsensor.boss: Vibration sensors detect physical movement and are used for security or equipment monitoring.
vibrationsensor.sysadmin: These sensors use accelerometers or piezoelectric elements to report shock/vibration events via Zigbee or BLE.
vibrationsensor.use_case: Used to detect if a window is hit or tampered with.

leaksensor.eli5: A leak sensor is like a smart towel that tells you when water shows up where it shouldn’t.
leaksensor.boss: Leak sensors detect water presence and notify you instantly to prevent damage.
leaksensor.sysadmin: Leak sensors use probes or conductive pads to detect moisture and transmit alerts via Zigbee, Z-Wave, or Wi-Fi.
leaksensor.use_case: Used to alert you if your washing machine leaks onto the floor.

watershutoffvalve.eli5: This gadget turns off the water for you if there's a leak.
watershutoffvalve.boss: Smart water shutoff valves can automatically cut off water supply when leaks are detected.
watershutoffvalve.sysadmin: These valves integrate with leak sensors and home automation systems via Z-Wave, Zigbee, or Wi-Fi for remote/manual control.
watershutoffvalve.use_case: Used to auto-shutoff water when a leak sensor triggers in the laundry room.

airqualitysensor.eli5: It’s a smart nose that can tell if the air is fresh or funky.
airqualitysensor.boss: Air quality sensors monitor pollutants and conditions like PM2.5 or VOCs for health and automation.
airqualitysensor.sysadmin: These sensors detect particulates, gases, and sometimes temperature/humidity, reporting data via Wi-Fi, Zigbee, or MQTT.
airqualitysensor.use_case: Used to run the air purifier when indoor pollution exceeds a safe level.

co/co2sensor.eli5: These are smart sniffers that alert you if there’s dangerous gas in the air.
co/co2sensor.boss: CO/CO2 sensors monitor carbon monoxide or dioxide levels for safety and air quality control.
co/co2sensor.sysadmin: CO sensors detect toxic gas using electrochemical tech; CO₂ sensors use NDIR and may report data over Zigbee or Wi-Fi.
co/co2sensor.use_case: Used to send an alert and turn on ventilation when CO₂ levels get too high indoors.

temperaturesensor.eli5: A smart thermometer that tells your home how warm or cold it is.
temperaturesensor.boss: Temperature sensors help automate climate control by feeding data to smart thermostats or triggers.
temperaturesensor.sysadmin: Sensors report real-time temperature readings over BLE, Zigbee, or MQTT and integrate into scenes or logic.
temperaturesensor.use_case: Used to adjust HVAC when a room gets too hot.

humiditysensor.eli5: It tells your home how sweaty or dry the air feels.
humiditysensor.boss: Humidity sensors track moisture levels to improve comfort and prevent issues like mold.
humiditysensor.sysadmin: These sensors provide relative humidity data via Zigbee, BLE, or MQTT for smart automations.
humiditysensor.use_case: Used to turn on a humidifier when the air is too dry.

lightsensor.eli5: It sees how bright it is and can tell lights when to turn on or off.
lightsensor.boss: Light sensors measure brightness and help automate lighting or blinds based on sunlight.
lightsensor.sysadmin: These sensors use photodiodes or LDRs to report lux levels, interfacing via Zigbee, MQTT, or GPIO.
lightsensor.use_case: Used to open blinds when sunlight is below a certain threshold.

occupancysensor.eli5: It figures out if someone is in the room—even if they’re not moving.
occupancysensor.boss: Occupancy sensors detect presence using advanced techniques beyond basic motion sensing.
occupancysensor.sysadmin: These use mmWave, ultrasonic, or radar sensing to determine presence, with high accuracy and continuous detection.
occupancysensor.use_case: Used to pause media when no one is in the room.

smartdoorbell.eli5: It’s a doorbell with a camera that tells you who’s there—even when you're not home.
smartdoorbell.boss: Smart doorbells combine video, motion alerts, and 2-way audio to enhance entryway awareness.
smartdoorbell.sysadmin: Smart doorbells use Wi-Fi to stream video, integrate with apps, record to cloud/local storage, and support automations.
smartdoorbell.use_case: Used to talk to delivery drivers from your phone even if you're away.

smartcamera.eli5: A smart camera watches over your home and lets you see from your phone.
smartcamera.boss: Smart cameras provide live monitoring, motion alerts, and cloud/local recording for home security.
smartcamera.sysadmin: Cameras stream video over RTSP, ONVIF, or proprietary protocols with motion detection, night vision, and API hooks.
smartcamera.use_case: Used to view live feeds of home areas and get alerts for motion.

indoorcamera.eli5: It’s a camera you put inside to see what’s happening at home.
indoorcamera.boss: Indoor cameras help monitor interior rooms for activity, pets, or security concerns.
indoorcamera.sysadmin: Typically Wi-Fi-based, these cameras support RTSP/cloud recording, motion alerts, and app integration.
indoorcamera.use_case: Used to check if pets are behaving while you're at work.

outdoorcamera.eli5: It’s a camera made to watch outside and not get ruined by rain or snow.
outdoorcamera.boss: Outdoor cameras provide exterior monitoring with weatherproofing and enhanced motion detection.
outdoorcamera.sysadmin: These IP65+ rated cameras stream over Wi-Fi or Ethernet, often supporting night vision, PIR, and cloud/local recording.
outdoorcamera.use_case: Used to detect people or vehicles approaching your driveway.

floodlightcamera.eli5: It’s a camera with a super bright light that turns on when someone walks by.
floodlightcamera.boss: Floodlight cameras combine outdoor security cameras with motion-triggered lighting.
floodlightcamera.sysadmin: These devices pair bright LED lights with PIR/motion sensors and smart camera streaming, typically over Wi-Fi.
floodlightcamera.use_case: Used to light up and record your yard when motion is detected at night.

petcamera.eli5: A pet camera lets you check on your furry friends when you’re away—and sometimes even talk to them.
petcamera.boss: Pet cameras offer live video, 2-way audio, and sometimes treat-dispensing to monitor and interact with pets remotely.
petcamera.sysadmin: These typically stream over Wi-Fi, support cloud recording, and offer app-based features like alerts or pan/tilt.
petcamera.use_case: Used to see and speak to your dog while you're at work.

smartspeaker.eli5: It’s a speaker that talks back and helps control your smart home.
smartspeaker.boss: Smart speakers combine voice assistant technology with music playback and smart home control.
smartspeaker.sysadmin: Smart speakers integrate with ecosystems like Alexa or Google, connect over Wi-Fi/Bluetooth, and act as smart hubs.
smartspeaker.use_case: Used to play music, control lights, and set timers with voice commands.

smartdisplay.eli5: A smart display is like a speaker with a screen that shows you things too.
smartdisplay.boss: Smart displays offer visual and voice-controlled interfaces for controlling your home and getting information.
smartdisplay.sysadmin: These devices run Google Assistant or Alexa, show video feeds, dashboards, and enable touchscreen interactions.
smartdisplay.use_case: Used to watch security camera feeds and control smart lights with a tap or voice.

intercomsystem.eli5: An intercom lets you talk to people in other rooms without yelling.
intercomsystem.boss: Smart intercoms allow 2-way communication across rooms or devices, often over Wi-Fi.
intercomsystem.sysadmin: These systems use mobile apps, BLE/Wi-Fi for audio transmission, and often integrate with doorbells or smart displays.
intercomsystem.use_case: Used to talk to kids in another room from your phone or smart display.

smarttv.eli5: A smart TV connects to the internet so you can watch shows without cable.
smarttv.boss: Smart TVs integrate streaming apps, voice assistants, and smart home dashboards into one display.
smarttv.sysadmin: Smart TVs run Android TV, Roku, Tizen, or WebOS and support integrations via APIs or casting protocols like DLNA/Chromecast.
smarttv.use_case: Used to stream Netflix and show your security camera feed on command.

irhub.eli5: An IR hub is like a smart remote that controls old-school devices with invisible beams.
irhub.boss: IR hubs centralize control of infrared-only devices through apps or automation platforms.
irhub.sysadmin: They emit IR signals using learned codes and expose them via LAN/cloud APIs, often paired with apps like BroadLink or Logitech Harmony.
irhub.use_case: Used to turn on an old TV using your phone or Alexa voice command.

irblaster.eli5: An IR blaster pretends to be a remote and presses buttons for you using light.
irblaster.boss: IR blasters simulate remote control commands to operate TVs, AC units, and other IR-based devices.
irblaster.sysadmin: IR blasters emit 38kHz-modulated signals to control consumer electronics via local API, RF pairing, or pre-coded commands.
irblaster.use_case: Used to control a legacy AC unit with automation routines in Home Assistant.

voiceassistant.eli5: It’s a robot voice that helps you do things when you talk to it.
voiceassistant.boss: Voice assistants like Alexa, Google Assistant, and Siri allow hands-free control of smart devices and services.
voiceassistant.sysadmin: Voice assistants process voice commands via cloud NLP, integrate with smart home APIs, and trigger routines or actions.
voiceassistant.use_case: Used to control lights, get weather, or trigger scenes by saying 'Good morning.'

routine.eli5: A routine is a list of things your smart home does together when you ask.
routine.boss: Routines are sequences of automated actions triggered by a voice command, schedule, or event.
routine.sysadmin: Routines execute predefined actions like toggling devices, speaking phrases, or running scripts based on triggers.
routine.use_case: Used to turn on lights, play music, and read the weather when you say 'Good morning.'

automation.eli5: It’s when your smart home does stuff by itself, like magic.
automation.boss: Automations trigger smart actions based on time, events, or sensor inputs without manual commands.
automation.sysadmin: Automations use if/then logic or YAML/flow editors in platforms like Home Assistant or Node-RED to trigger device behavior.
automation.use_case: Used to turn off all lights and lock doors when everyone leaves home.

scene.eli5: A scene is like a preset that sets your lights, music, and temperature just right.
scene.boss: Scenes let you control multiple devices with one command for moods, activities, or events.
scene.sysadmin: Scenes define the target state of devices and are executed manually or via routines, automations, or voice.
scene.use_case: Used to set a 'Movie Night' scene with dimmed lights and AV equipment powered on.

modetrigger.eli5: A mode tells your smart home what you’re doing—like ‘Away’ or ‘Sleeping.’
modetrigger.boss: Modes are global states that let your automations behave differently based on overall home context.
modetrigger.sysadmin: Modes act as conditional states (e.g., Home, Away, Night) used in rule engines to adjust automation logic.
modetrigger.use_case: Used to enable security alerts only when the mode is set to 'Away.'

presencedetection.eli5: Your smart home notices when you're home—or not—and acts accordingly.
presencedetection.boss: Presence detection lets your home change behavior based on whether someone is present.
presencedetection.sysadmin: Achieved via GPS, network ping, Bluetooth, or occupancy sensors, and triggers automation rules based on presence.
presencedetection.use_case: Used to turn on lights when someone arrives and disable them when everyone leaves.

geofencing.eli5: Your phone draws a magic circle around your house to know when you come or go.
geofencing.boss: Geofencing uses your phone’s GPS to trigger smart actions when entering or leaving a defined area.
geofencing.sysadmin: Geofencing sets location-based triggers using mobile GPS and apps like Home Assistant, IFTTT, or Alexa.
geofencing.use_case: Used to unlock the front door and turn on lights when you arrive home.

roombasedautomation.eli5: Each room in your house can do its own smart tricks when someone’s there.
roombasedautomation.boss: Room-based automation triggers actions specific to individual spaces based on sensors or activity.
roombasedautomation.sysadmin: This uses motion, light, or presence sensors assigned to rooms to scope automations within areas.
roombasedautomation.use_case: Used to turn on bathroom lights when motion is detected—without affecting the rest of the house.

devicegrouping.eli5: Grouping lets you control lots of things together—like turning off all lights at once.
devicegrouping.boss: Device grouping lets multiple devices be controlled as one—for ease of use and automation.
devicegrouping.sysadmin: Groups are logical collections defined in hubs or platforms to send a single command to multiple devices.
devicegrouping.use_case: Used to turn off all lights in a room with one voice command.

energymonitoring.eli5: It’s like a smart meter that tells you how much electricity your gadgets are using.
energymonitoring.boss: Energy monitoring lets users track electricity usage to save power and optimize automation.
energymonitoring.sysadmin: Devices use current sensors (CT clamps or shunt resistors) to measure energy consumption and report via MQTT, Zigbee, or REST APIs.
energymonitoring.use_case: Used to identify which devices are using too much power and automate based on that.
